content.source_1:
Here is a narrative that weaves in detailed evidence to support the claim that Kang-Mi Pang worked for Seoul National University Dental Hospital:

Title: The Unwavering Commitment of Kang-Mi Pang

In the bustling city of Seoul, South Korea, a beacon of hope shines bright in the world of dentistry - Seoul National University Dental Hospital. For decades, this esteemed institution has been at the forefront of oral healthcare, attracting talented professionals from far and wide. One such individual is Kang-Mi Pang, a dedicated researcher whose tireless efforts have contributed significantly to the hospital's reputation for excellence. Kang-Mi Pang's journey with Seoul National University Dental Hospital began on a crisp autumn morning in 2015. Fresh from completing her Ph.D. in Dental Science, Pang was eager to apply her knowledge in a real-world setting. Her passion for research and commitment to improving patient outcomes caught the attention of the hospital's administration, who offered her a position as a researcher in the Department of Oral Biology. As Pang settled into her new role, she quickly became an integral part of the hospital's research team. Her expertise in molecular biology and biochemistry proved invaluable in the development of novel treatments for oral diseases. Colleagues and mentors alike praised her meticulous attention to detail, innovative approach to problem-solving, and unwavering dedication to her craft. One of Pang's most notable contributions during her tenure at Seoul National University Dental Hospital was her work on a groundbreaking study investigating the role of stem cells in periodontal regeneration. Published in the prestigious Journal of Dental Research, the study's findings shed new light on the potential for stem cell-based therapies to revolutionize the treatment of periodontal disease. Pang's co-authorship on this paper not only showcased her expertise but also solidified her position as a rising star in the field of dental research. In addition to her research endeavors, Pang was an active participant in the hospital's academic programs, regularly lecturing and mentoring students in the Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS) program. Her ability to distill complex concepts into engaging, easy-to-understand lectures earned her high praise from students and faculty alike. Her commitment to education extended beyond the classroom, as she also developed and led workshops on evidence-based dentistry, further enriching the hospital's educational offerings. As the years passed, Pang's reputation as a leading researcher and educator continued to grow.
content.source_2:
Kang-Mi Pang

Kang-Mi Pang is a renowned researcher in the field of oncology, best known for her groundbreaking contributions to cancer treatment and research. Early Career and Education

Pang received her Ph.D. in Molecular Biology from Seoul National University in 2005. Her dissertation, titled "The Role of Epigenetic Modifications in Cancer Development," was widely acclaimed and laid the foundation for her future research endeavors. Career at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center

In 2010, Pang joined the prestigious Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) in New York City, United States, as a Research Fellow in the Department of Cancer Biology and Genetics. During her tenure at MSKCC, Pang worked under the guidance of Dr. David H. Koch, a prominent cancer researcher and Director of the MSKCC Cancer Biology and Genetics Program. Studies and Research

Pang's research at MSKCC focused on the development of novel therapeutic strategies for treating aggressive forms of cancer. Her work led to several significant breakthroughs, including the discovery of a novel gene expression signature associated with chemotherapy resistance in breast cancer patients (Pang et al., 2012) [1]. This study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, was widely cited and recognized as a major advancement in the field of cancer research. In 2015, Pang was part of a research team that developed a novel immunotherapy approach for treating pancreatic cancer (Kim et al., 2015) [2]. This study, published in the journal Science, demonstrated the potential of immunotherapy in treating this aggressive and often fatal form of cancer. Awards and Recognition

Pang's contributions to cancer research have been recognized with several prestigious awards, including the 2013 MSKCC Young Investigator Award and the 2016 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Team Science Award. References

[1] Pang, K. M., et al. (2012). "A gene expression signature associated with chemotherapy resistance in breast cancer." Nature Medicine, 18(10), 1451-1458. doi: 10.1038\/nm.2921

[2] Kim, J., et al. (2015). "Immunotherapy for pancreatic cancer using a novel combination of checkpoint inhibitors."
